--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kris Henderson" <khenderson@p...> wrote:
> Hi Jim,
> 
> It took me a while to figure out what was going on here.  I think 
> what is happening is that assert equals uses "..." for equal parts 
> of the expected and actual values.  So in your example, "<... ...> 
> but was <......>" means that there was not a space where it expected
> one to be.
> 
> assertEquals("foobar", "abc", "abc123") would print:
> Foobar expected: <...> but was <...123>

Yes, That's correct.  Personally, I'd like this behaviour to kick in
when the strings are long... say over 12 characters.  I'd also like
them to give adequate context...  maybe 2 or 3 characters on each side
of the difference as possible.

> If you don't like this behavior you can always implement your own
> version of assertEquals.

Yes, you can alwasy make a subclass of TestCase to put your own
assertion methods and have your test classes extend that.

In this case, it isn't assertEquals(String, String, String) that is
the culprit.  It's ComparisonFailure.getMessage().

Dave
